H0.text: The plants used to be harvested for food, as suggested by finding fossils of warm‑weather plants in the rock layers of a cold northern island.

H1.text: The island used to be located farther south, as suggested by finding fossils of warm‑weather plants in the rock layers of a cold northern island.

H2.text: The climate of the island used to be warmer, as indicated by finding fossils of warm‑weather plants in the rock layers of a cold northern island.

H3.text: The fossils used to be more resistant to cold, as indicated by finding fossils of warm‑weather plants in the rock layers of a cold northern island.

A4.text: Pollen has been observed in the ice cores and can be used to understand which plants were present as the layer formed.

A5.text: The presence or absence of land masses at the poles is not sufficient to guarantee glaciations or exclude polar ice caps.
